A best practice is to train and instil the habit of PKM in as many employees as possible. This allows the philosophy of knowledge to permeate the entire structure of the company, to become part of its DNA.
Adhering to PKM practices solves the problem that KBs remain unclaimed in many companies. In addition, you have to include the use of KB in daily work.

Who might be interested in the experiment: business owners, C-level executives, knowledge and other managers, researchers and those who consume a lot of information and want to improve the output through Personal knowledge management

During The Experiment, I decided to keep a length note limit equal to the tweet size1: 280 characters without links The character limit allows being laser-focused on one thought and keeps Content Boxes straightforward and minimal.

The Knowledge base (KB) is based on the Zettelkasten methodology. KB is not an encyclopedia. Its purpose is to provide the minimum necessary information to set the right direction for further research.
The KnowledgeBase has three levels: Zettels Content Boxes: Zettels containers in_progress/Map of Content Box: Content Boxes outliners Each of them has its own set of tags.
Zettelkasten Note or Zettel is a minimal semantic unit, info-atom and the basic level of the Knowledge Base. The basic rule is
Ask Why every time you start a project. More than once. It will help at first materialize your idea in words.
Five Ws (sometimes referred to as Five Ws and How, 5W1H, or Six Ws) are questions whose answers are considered essential in information gathering or solving problems.

Following the 5Ws principles provides a solid Knowledge Base structure and thus structures information → knowledge. Also, it will be easy to write and find the information knowing how the KB is arranged.
What is the very first question you should ask during project requirements collection for your project to define the scope.
Remember Who your stakeholders are: team, client, sponsor, etc. Who ultimately benefits when your project is completed?
Sometimes When is the most critical question. You will fail even if you do everything right but at the wrong time.
Where will your project be done? Where will it be delivered? With today’s global and dispersed environments, this question is not as simple as it may seem!
Each question should have a factual answer – facts necessary to include for a report to be considered complete. Importantly, none of these questions can be answered with a simple yes or no.
Ask How only when all core questions have been answered. This is where the methods, best practices, tools and techniques get deployed… but not until you have answered in detail the 5 Ws first!
When writing a thought, I recommend keeping it within 100-200 words: that’s about five notes in the size of a tweet.
Following the 5Ws, one of the values1 is written to note tags in YAML format: [opening, who, what, when, where, why, how, closing] Find the source of the current note on Google Drive as an example.

I’ve been using these tools for a while and suppose their combination can provide a synergy effect. Based on the results and experience I gained, I want to implement knowledge management into WRIO work processes.

Goal Develop a solid concept for creating a goal-achieving corporate KnowledgeBase + business process automation Concept should incorporates the principles of Sociocracy, Kaizen, TRIZ and in_progress/Raw/Ad-hoc into the processes1.
I create Content Boxes according to the 5Ws: opening – introduction, description what why who when where how closing – conclusions, links, related opening and closing are auxiliary.
Content Boxes (CBs) are the 2nd level of the KnowledgeBase and contain Zettels. I recommend keeping CBs completely blank, without even headers, inserting Zettelkasten notes only.
Each block is represented by one or more Zettels I recommend adhering to the structure and section order of the 5Ws1.
